- onset: abrupt, rapidly progressive, gradual

- presence of fever, purpura

- presence of meningeal syndrome

- presence of oculomotor disorders

- trauma (bruising, haematoma in the eyeglass or retroauricular area)

- convulsions, myoclonus

- context :

o chronic intoxication: alcohol, illicit substances

o farewell letter, empty blister packs

o Empty syringes, injection marks

o prescriptions for oral antidiabetics or insulin

o dilapidated accommodation, heating methods (CO ...)

question.title: What is a common cause of non-traumatic coma in adults and children?

option_a.title: Trauma to the head or neck
option_a.description: Physical injury to the head or neck can cause non-traumatic coma

option_b.title: Chronic intoxication with alcohol or illicit substances
option_b.description: Long-term substance abuse can lead to non-traumatic coma

option_c.title: Meningitis or encephalitis
option_c.description: Infections of the meninges or brain can cause non-traumatic coma

option_d.title: Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia
option_d.description: Abnormal blood sugar levels can cause non-traumatic coma
